TopicTitle: Joystick sensitivity options have no numerical values (that I can find).

Articles.Content:
I'm trying to setup a joystick for my game and I want to alter the sensitivity (the default feels too sensitive and twitchy), and I'm a bit perplexed at the lack of input from the slide bars.

The default one (the second orange circle) does have a kind of... "snap to" aspect to it, so if you want to put it back to default then the game understand what you want to do and puts it there for you.  But there's no such "snap" option for 50% normal, or 25%.  Just a little numerical indicator would be really nice.  Is this possible?

 

Edited January 7, 2016 by PTNLemay

In my settings.cfg file for KSP, around line 875 I see various lines that correlate to what you're seeing on the options screen (i.e. "primary", "secondary", "roll axis"). In those same items in the settings.cfg file, I see numerical values for sensitivity and deadzone. 

While it isn't a convenient in-game display, you could make changes in the settings GUI and then evaluate the values in the settings.cfg file to get an idea of a numerical value.

Edited January 7, 2016 by Bandus

Or I could just edit the cfg files themselves?   Or are they some kind of... read-only thing?

I also found that even at the minimum value, the thing is still too sensitive. While flying I make adjustments of a few degrees, and it's like... "Oh, overshot!  Bring it back."  Or does "sensitivity" mean something else?

This is the joystick that I've got (if it makes any difference).  http://www.amazon.com/Thrustmaster-T-Flight-Hotas-Flight-Playstation-3/dp/B001CXYMFS

I also turned "dead-zone" down to a minimum, because I've always understood that to be a negative.  That's the middle area of the joystick where you can wiggle it a bit and it won't register as movement, right?.  You have to push it passed a point and then the game actually sees it.

Edited January 7, 2016 by PTNLemay

Unfortunately, I don't really use a joystick myself for KSP. I found it to be less precise then keyboard controls, oddly enough.

As far as the settings.cfg, it is NOT read-only by default so I don't see any reason why you couldn't change the values in it.
